comments.commentBody:
Of course I am, John. I've said more than once you're a master raconteur, Prose is your metier. When limericks appear in the puzzle, toss some off if you like, but I bet you would have knocked our socks off with a couple of paragraphs *about* limericks.

Have seen no mention of today's avatar, and am still in limbo. Who's the young man?

You can lay this at the feet of President Obama if you want to, MH, but you do so at the expense of truth.
Unfortunately, the last century is full of examples of presidents and other elected federal officials trampling on certain groups' rights in the name of security. The internment of Japanese Americans during World War II, blacklisting, McCarthyism, law-enforcement infiltration of civil rights and peace groups, etc.
And then we have the example of the actions of the GW Bush administration after 9/11.
Meanwhile, in the process of bashing the president for saying his job is to keep the American people safe, you not only do injustice to the truth, but also to the Constitution, which you seem to hold sacred while being completely oblivious to what it says.
When the president vows to faithfully execute his duties, one of those duties is being commander in chief of the military. If the military isn't around to keep us safe, then I'm not sure what it's here for.

Almost as bad as the content of Mr. Rubio's response to the SOTU address was his juvenile delivery. His voice in all his neervousness went up about an octave and he his facial expression flipped from deadpan to rictus.

Then we know that the content of the speech was written before the SOTU had even been formulated. The zombie economics Professor Krugman cites here was not a response to President Obama, it was a catechism--a litany of standard Republican talking points without one scintilla of wit, originality or spontineity.

So this is the best the Republicans have to offer at this point? Really? If Mr. Rubio can't hack a short television appearance, how is he going to govern he the nation. If he has not one new idea, how is he going to meet the challenges of governing as the nation's priorities evolve.

I am almost sorry for the Republicans. Their old guard is being beaten up and discredited by their own followers. Their young guard like Rubio are far from being ready for prime time.

But I am also nervous. If the best ideas the younger generation has are being generated by Paul Ryan, Eric Cantor and Marco Rubio, heaven help us. Their economic ideas range from ineffective to crazy. We would not survive a presidency under their control.

I agree with much of what you said and have expressed my belief that we Democrats were being overoptimistic. A single unpredictable disaster could cost us the next election.

That being said, those shifts in power weren't just the result of adverse events or unsuccessful presidencies. The Democrats, for example, moved back to the center after the Reagan sweep and the repeated failures of the McGovern/Jesse Jackson years, and have essentially remained there ever since. Similarly, the Republicans moved to the left after the FDR years.

I've long believed that the Republicans would have to move back to center and, in a rational world, they would have, but the problem is that the voters in their primaries are far to the right. So the party is stuck.

Furthermore, you speak of black or Hispanic candidates, but this is of little account. People may be more likely to vote for a candidate who is like them, but they aren't so likely that they'll vote for a candidate who is opposed to their interestes -- and right now, the GOP stands for the interests of a few white guys.

So yeah, we Democrats are probably over-confident -- but the Republicans are utterly clueless if they think they can prosper as a party by holding extremist views and attacking blacks, women, gays, urbanites, atheists, liberals, moderates, the educated, the poor, union members, students, the working class, the elderly, and everybody who isn't a card-carrying white male member of the 99%.

President Obama hinted at one strategy in the SOTU address Tuesday night worth noting as a means to counter GOP intransigence: use Executive Orders to bypass the Congress on key legislative items. He needs to stretch the Elastic Clause to its limits even if some in the Republican Party call him 'dictator'. They did the same to FDR and he shrugged it off as the usual partisanship.

The other strategy worth pursuing is a 2014 mid term election campaign unseen in American history for its vitality to serve up a shellacking the republicans will never forget. This strategy is more problematic because historically, Americans don't get excited about off-year elections. But 2014 is different and without a surge of voter Interest, President Obama's second term could be jeopardized by inertia.
If I see each person as having within them what we love about "humanity," it becomes easier for me to feel compassion about a person in their present damaged state.

For tenderness to have teeth, so to speak, I believe (and others have hinted at this in the comments here) that it must also have a rugged particularity or specificity about it, as well as measurable and objective action, otherwise it can collapse into maudlin sentimentality.  I think it was G.K. Chesterton who, in one of his cheeky and puckish satiric comments on the liberal mindset, wrote, "I love humanity.  It's people I can't stand," or something to this effect.  One ought not fall victim to theoretical good will and good intentions towards all humanity when but one person is in front of you.  Of course, here I may be eliding tenderness and a classical version of caritas, or charity.

"Marco Rubio and his Party continue to promote the policies that created the financial crisis and the Great Recession of 2008. History will show the party of Rubio, Bush, Gingrich, Ryan and Bohner nearly drove the country off a cliff, all the while enriching their billionaire clients like the Koch brothers.
Instead of accepting responsibility for their negligent stewardship of the treasure of our nation and the lives of its brave men and women in uniform, they strut about the Halls of Congress, insisting that if given another chance they will bring us prosperity, peace, and security. No one is fooled by their stories...only the willfully ignorant and those with ulterior motives that profit only themselves would join with such as these."
How's that?
The President sent 9 jobs bills to Congress, none of which were considered in the House. Look them up.

Okay, so we know that in the housing bubble the Republicans were wrong, in the aftermath they were wrong. In the 90's, when Glass-Steagall was repealed at Republican behest, they were wrong. (note: Clinton signed the repeal and Obama retained Bush's economic team that "created" the collapse...)

But why do Liberals and Liberal-leaning pundits find it necessary to try and convince Republicans of their wrongness instead of just pushing louder for their own rightness? It seems to me that that is just playing on "their field and their rules" - validating their claims by making efforts to discuss them.

Instead of spending gobs of time declaring their positions wrong-headed, how about we spend gobs of time detailing how "the correct plan" should or could be enacted and is the way to go... and just shush the Republicans.

How about this:
"Marco Rubio continued promoting the failed and false policies of his Party. However, President Obama touched on a few issues that really need detailing. How exactly could a jobs program be enacted? Well we have an example in, of all places, Greece..." etc.

Let's get some focus on the "Liberal" proposals and only on the "GOP" proposals when it's worth talking about. Whaddayasay?

Thank you, Dr. K. I imagine it is tiresome to repeat yet again the most basic fundamental, and yet more tiresome to know those saying these things will not ever listen.

We need to hear it. We need someone to say it clearly for us. One more time.

In Supremo Apostolatus:
This is why, desiring to remove such a shame from all the Christian nations, having fully reflected over the whole question and having taken the advice of many of Our Venerable Brothers the Cardinals of the Holy Roman Church, and walking in the footsteps of Our Predecessors, We warn and adjure earnestly in the Lord faithful Christians of every condition that no one in the future dare to vex anyone, despoil him of his possessions, reduce to servitude, or lend aid and favour to those who give themselves up to these practices, or exercise that inhuman traffic by which the Blacks, as if they were not men but rather animals, having been brought into servitude, in no matter what way, are, without any distinction, in contempt of the rights of justice and humanity, bought, sold, and devoted sometimes to the hardest labour. Further, in the hope of gain, propositions of purchase being made to the first owners of the Blacks, dissensions and almost perpetual conflicts are aroused in these regions.

We reprove, then, by virtue of Our Apostolic Authority, all the practices abovementioned as absolutely unworthy of the Christian name. By the same Authority We prohibit and strictly forbid any Ecclesiastic or lay person from presuming to defend as permissible this traffic in Blacks under no matter what pretext or excuse, or from publishing or teaching in any manner whatsoever, in public or privately, opinions contrary to what We have set forth in this Apostolic Letter.

I just read an article about Greece, asserting that unemployment before the austerity measures were enacted was about 9%, and now, it's unofficially about 27%. Soon, a third of the Greek people will be impoverished.

I pray that America will avoid this fate. Austerity measures in Great Britain have caused nothing but economic woe. Making people suffer won't help the economy, period.

As for Rubio and the zombies, well, yes it's disturbing. We can look at our own past, at the Depression, at the policies that created it, we can look at the present in Europe, and see the results of insane fiscal policies, crushing the life out of nations, economies, and people. Hearing that these policies are good is alarming.

The argument over the minimum wage speaks to this absurdity. Raising the minimum wage would help business because people would have more money to spend and it would also increase revenues to the government, thus lowering the deficit. Forcing people to work for peanuts, though - that's a guaranteed recipe for disaster. There's so much good will and creativity here - don't crush it!

Maybe, enough Americans will have started to realize that GOP ideas have resulted in economic and social calamity. Polls certainly seem to indicate this.

It would be deeply gratifying if Congress would represent the best interests of the people and not just the rich. My own sense is that they've gone too far this time, beating the dead horse of voodoo economics. Time for a change.
Yep, looks like its gettin' late early for Andy this year...
He said it, you just don't like the way it was spelled.
I'd be curious if Jerome from Minneapolis knows the singular of Sox.  How else is Pat Borzi supposed to write it?

I've never used anything else for the singular of "Red Sox," or bothered to give a moment's thought to the possibility that was somehow "wrong." What would you say? "Red Soxer?" "Red Sox Player?" "Man with socks of scarlet?"

Please. "Sox" is an archaic alternate spelling of "socks." Putting "red" or "white" in front of it doesn't change the fact that the singular of it is "sock."

Pat Borzi: If you want to make a career out of this sports-writing thing, you better learn the lingo. Unless Youk is taking up residence in a laundromat, it's highly unlikely he said, “I will always be a Red Sock."

I've no doubt scribes said the same thing when the printing press came along: "Oh, where will you find ink if the Muslims invade?"

Or coach drivers: "Where will that motorcar get you if the gas runs out"?

As it happens, we were prepared during the blizzard with a generator, lots of gas, three fully-charged Kindles two of them 3G, a fully charged netbook, two cell phones, two land lines with self-powered phones, and LCD lanterns, flashlights, and power failure lights. So you see, one really needn't return to the dark age to survive a blackout.

If there's common sense in living with the technological limitations of the past to avoid non-existent difficulties in the present, well, you conservatives are welcome to it.

"Gambling is the worst because an alky or druggie would die LONG before blowing a billion on their habit."

Wow. So it's worse to be a gambler, finally in recovery, looking to repay the millions owed, than to be dead in the gutter because it takes "only" a few hundred thousand dollars worth of drugs or booze to eventually kill oneself?

Perhaps the lesson here is that gambling IS an addiction -- an illness. Sorry to see you are more upset with millions of dollars she squandered than the prospect of another troubled human being's senseless death. Valuing money over human life is sadly becoming the norm for many and your comment captures that succinctly.
Doesn't that make drugs and alcohol worse?

John, among that 13 million was millions she stole from a charity.  Sure, it ain't a billion dollars but it wasn't exactly her money either.  And this brain tumor excuse is pathetic.  Even MLB steroid user-deniers are laughing.

Tose lost his case on his first try then abandoned further attempts. Leonard Tose gambled, drank and lost. Casinos don't get people drunk. People order the drinks, then they drink them. Blaming others for your own vices is the height of irresponsibility. At least this lady takes responsibility for her actions.

I am also reminded of Leonard (?) Tose, the former Philadelphia Eagle's owner and trucking magnate.  Didn't he sue some AC casinos after they would continually get him drunk and he would blow millions?
She bet a billion and only lost 13 million? Sounds like she did pretty well.

Why is it the casinos' responsibility to stop her?  Was it their responsibility to get her treatment for her "grief gambling" (the new "Twinkie defense")?  With all due respect, what happened to personal responsibility?  In the alternative, where were her family and her financial advisors, who should have noticed?  Also, I'd point fingers at the foundation's board and auditors long before the casinos.
Indeed. If it's the law that a bartender has to cut someone off who's had too much to drink, shouldn't casinos be required to do the same?

The casinos knew that she was an obsessed gambler who was gambling away
millions of dollars. Decent people do not let other people do grievous damage to
themselves, particularly when there is a simple way of preventing it. (What is really needed here are governmentally-imposed limits on how much people will
be allowed to lose in casinos.)
The gambling casinos were criminal in allowing her to do this.

No. It's a tenth of that: $13 million is 1.3% of $1 billion (and it was over nine years).

Which is not all that unusual if you stick to low-risk games.

Actually, she did really well. $13M lost over ten years with $1B or $1000M is only a 1.3% total loss. She slew it. I wonder how much she was up at her best.....

But honestly, $300K a day? Man that is really hard to even comprehend.
$300,000 a day means she treated it like a profession.
If you think about it she actually didn't do that bad as a gambler in the loss win for the amount and period of time only a 13% average loss of total money bet in ten years of high stakes gaming...

Can I ask you a question? How is it possible to remain so isolated from objective information that you actually believe what you hear on Fox News? Because, you know, all that talk about the country failing epically or Obama worship is quite nonsensical.

Your party has been badly trapped by this propaganda operation it set up. Its own primary voters are now so badly misinformed that it's preventing the party from doing anything sensible -- and the majority of voters have come to see that.
Marie Antoinette was so disconnected from the people she didn't even realise that the poor had neither cake nor bread. Our contemporary elite know quite well what's going on outside their bubble.

I agree, There's something about this "backwardness" we have - that we start off thinking we have a democracy which then devolves to a plutocracy - that is so disturbing.

The American Revolution, and the US founded, to break from class domination. So 250 years later, we have returned to early 18th century values. Progress?

yes, but along with the right-wing political manuverings begun more than 30 years ago, comes the change in school programs, additives to the food supply- all designed to create a population too overweight, too ignorant, too tired to rise up.

Half of the public is already angry. The rest of the public is "under the influence".

I was born into an egalitarian society and it looks like I will die in a feudal society. The confidence that the middle and working classes had about our place in the world and their ability to make a decent living has been shattered in a mere 3 decades. We didn't understand how what a fragile thing true meritocracy is. We were too smug, too confident for our own good. We decided that we were too busy to pay attention to what was happening under our noses. We ignored the warnings. There was the savings and loan scandal, then there was the dot.com bubble, followed by the housing bubble. The bubbles combined with very elastic credit enabled our ignorance by disguising the reality of our flattening salaries and eroding rights at work.

In short, most of us took a 30 year political nap and woke up into a total nightmare. Suddenly we knew that we had a disastrous economic mess and a government corrupt beyond our wildest imaginations.

I keep hoping that these issues could be resolved through aggressive legislation. We had high hopes in 2008 that all it would take is a massive legislative push to undo the damage. But we found out the hard way, just how seriously entrenched the corruption by the actually was.

The one thing the 1% don't realize and that's that the public anger at the erosion of their prosperity can be far greater than they imagine. Wasn't it Marie Antoinette that said "let them eat cake"?
Remember the zombies are those who follow without a clue.
You greatly overestimate the acuity of the voting public. Let's not forget the last election was a horse race, despite the fact that everything the losing candidates said were lies.

Marco Rubio is just a prepackaged fellow of a different flavor but the taste is the same one we all had to bitterly spit from our mouths in Sept 2008. The failure  of supply side trickle down economics, low tax, unregulated oversight from the federal gov't over the financial industry which accounts for approx 63% of our total economy. The absurd notion put forth by Marco Rubio that we are still to believe gov't is bad, the free market will control itself and all will be well if we just follow the same course of economics we've been in since the mid 1980's is just that , absurd. Only a real moron, a person lacking any hindsight could even attempt to sell to the American public what Rubio did. He proved himself the perfect rube. If the United States is to recover economically it will only happen when the republican economic theories put in place that have failed so miserably are recognized by those poor to middle class white voters who are sold the God, Guns & Gays mantra of the far right wake up smell the coffee and realize they have been played for fools by their beloved republican congressmen and women from the deep south across to Texas and up the rise of the great plains of Oklahoma, Nebraska, Wyoming to Idaho. These republican operatives have so maligned what are called Eastern elitists ( I would qualify)  as they claim we wish to impose our lifestyle or morals and ethics upon those they prey on for votes. They stir the pot of division to win, in the end we all lose

We don't have a spending problem, it isn't even at record levels of GDP. Interest rates would only go up if the economy improved, at which point tax revenues would go up as well. It doesn't really matter, since in essence the government owes money to itself. The economy doesn't work like your checkbook because the government has the power to print currency. That means that the amount of money it prints and borrows is determined by inflation and economic growth rates, not by cash on hand or ability to repay.

What is most discouraging is the complete power that each party seems to have over their members.  Obviously, even a Senator is not at liberty to vote against their party without serious repercussions.  As long as the parties hold this power, nothing is going to change in Washington.
